title: What is Programming, Really?
concept:
Imagine you're teaching a very literal-minded friend how to make a peanut butter and jelly sandwich. You can't just say 'make a sandwich'—you have to break it down into tiny, specific steps:

  1. Pick up the bread bag
  2. Open the bag
  3. Take out two slices of bread
  4. Place them on the counter
  5. Pick up the jar of peanut butter
  6. Twist the lid counter-clockwise to open it
  7. ...and so on

That's exactly what programming is.

A computer is like that very literal friend. It's incredibly fast and never gets tired, but it only does exactly what you tell it to do, in exactly the order you tell it. If you forget a step or put them in the wrong order, it won't figure it out—it'll either do the wrong thing or stop and say "I don't understand."

Python is the language you'll use to give these instructions. Just like English or Spanish is a language humans use to communicate, Python is a language humans use to communicate with computers.

The beautiful thing? Python was designed to be as close to plain English as possible, so it reads almost like a recipe or a set of instructions you'd give to a friend.

code_example.code:
# This is your first Python program!
# The '#' symbol creates a comment - notes for humans that the computer ignores

# Tell the computer to print (display) a message
print("Hello, World!")

# That's it! This simple instruction tells Python:
# "Show the text 'Hello, World!' on the screen"

syntax_breakdown:
Let's break down what just happened:

  • print() - This is a function (we'll learn more about these later). Think of it as a command or action word, like 'display' or 'show'. It tells Python: 'take whatever is inside the parentheses and show it to the user.'
  • ("Hello, World!") - The parentheses ( ) are like a lunchbox—they carry the information that print needs. Inside, we have "Hello, World!" wrapped in quotes.
  • "Hello, World!" - The quotation marks tell Python: 'This is text (what programmers call a string), not a command.' Without quotes, Python would think Hello is a command and get confused.
  • # - Everything after a # on a line is a comment. Python completely ignores it. Comments are notes you leave for yourself or other programmers to explain what the code does.

Why does this matter? Because if you wrote print(Hello, World!) without quotes, Python would say 'Error! I don't know what Hello is!' The quotes are crucial.

exercise.instructions:

exercise.starter_code:
# Welcome to your first Python exercise!
# Replace the ____ below with the correct code

____("Your message here")

# Bonus: Add another print() line below to display a second message
exercise.hint:
Hint: The command to display text is print. Remember to keep the quotation marks around your message!

Your code should look like: print("Your message here")

solution.code:
# Welcome to your first Python exercise!
# Here's the solution!

print("Your message here")

# Bonus: Here's a second print statement
print("I'm learning Python!")

# You could have written ANY message, like:
# print("My name is Alice")
# print("Python is fun!")
# print("2025 is my year!")
solution.explanation:
How it works:

  1. print is the command that tells Python to display something
  2. The parentheses () contain what you want to display
  3. The quotation marks "" tell Python this is text (a string), not code
  4. You can write ANY text inside the quotes—it's your message!

For the bonus, you simply added another print() line. Python reads your code from top to bottom, so it displays the first message, then the second.
solution.common_mistakes:
⚠️ Common Sticking Points:

  1. Forgetting the quotation marks:

    print(Hello)  ❌ Wrong - Python thinks Hello is a variable
print("Hello")  ✅ Correct - Python knows this is text

  2. Misspelling 'print':

    Print("Hello")  ❌ Wrong - capital P
PRINT("Hello")  ❌ Wrong - all caps
print("Hello")  ✅ Correct - lowercase 'print'

    Python is case-sensitive! print and Print are different things.

  3. Forgetting the parentheses:

    print "Hello"  ❌ Wrong in Python 3
print("Hello")  ✅ Correct

  4. Mixing up quote types mid-string:

    print("Hello')  ❌ Wrong - starts with " but ends with '
print("Hello")  ✅ Correct - matching quotes
print('Hello')  ✅ Also correct - single quotes work too!

Pro Tip: Both double quotes "" and single quotes '' work in Python, but you must be consistent within each string!

key_takeaways:
• Programming is like giving very detailed, step-by-step instructions to a computer
  • Python is a language designed to be readable and beginner-friendly
  • print() is your first Python command—it displays text on the screen
  • Text (strings) must be wrapped in quotation marks: "like this" or 'like this'
  • Comments (lines starting with #) are notes for humans—Python ignores them
  • Python is case-sensitive: print works, but Print doesn't
